newsitem.title: USA: Chairman of large minority-owned bond firm resigns.
newsitem.headline: Chairman of large minority-owned bond firm resigns.

text.p: The chairman of one of the nation's largest minority-owned investment banking firms resigned on Tuesday.

Calvin B. Grigsby resigned as chairman of San Francisco-based Grigsby Brandford & Co., according to a news release by the firm. The move comes a week after it was disclosed that he paid a fine for making campaign gifts in California without full disclosure.
Grigsby, the long-time chairman of the minority-owned firm he founded in 1981, could not be reached for comment.
In Tuesday's news release, he said that he was "looking forward to this as a major intersection in my life after a career devoted primarily to Grigsby Brandford & Co."
"I'm proud of Grigsby Brandford, the contribution it has made, and I'm eager to pursue new opportunities at this stage in my life," he said.

The investment banking and financial advisory firm underwrites, sells and trades municipal bonds, preferred stock, Treasury notes and other government securities. It is the only Black-owned investment bank to rank in the top 15 senior managers of tax-exempt financial deals.

Napoleon Brandford was named board chairman by the private firm's shareholders. Suzanne Shank, a managing director for Grigsby Brandford based in the Midwest, was named president and chief executive officer, according to the release.
Earlier this month, California state officials disclosed that Grigsby had paid a $5,000 fine for making campaign contributions without full and complete disclosure.
In an interview last week, Grigsby said the press was exaggerating the campaign contribution violations.
"I don't consider this a major item. To me, it's not a big deal because it's just a reporting violation," he said. "Somehow, the press has made it look a lot more than that."
"Why that happens, I think, has a lot to do with their interest in the fact that I'm an African American," Grigsby said. "I think there's some character assassination there," he added.
